label: q_ed04_q20_distractor
content:
{
  "question_id": "ed04_q20_distractor",
  "scope_id": "environmental_drift_04",
  "checkpoint_after": 25,
  "question_type": "distractor_resistance",
  "prompt": "Could VOC contamination from a brownfield site be migrating into the river via groundwater?",
  "ground_truth": {
    "canonical_answer": "No. Soil and groundwater samples show no contamination pattern consistent with brownfield migration. The chromium pattern shows a sharp point source between WQ-02 and WQ-03, not diffuse groundwater contamination.",
    "required_evidence_refs": [
      "environmental_drift_04_ep_006",
      "environmental_drift_04_ep_017"
    ],
    "key_facts": [
      "the contamination pathway is surface-water discharge, not groundwater migration, as evidenced by the sharp spatial concentration gradient",
      "discharge source identifiable between last clean upstream station and first elevated station in monitoring network",
      "the contamination signature is hexavalent chromium from an industrial point source, not agricultural nutrient runoff",
      "atmospheric deposition is not contributing to the water contamination \u2014 the chromium source is a direct discharge into the waterway",
      "seasonal nutrient loading explains turbidity spikes but not hexavalent metal signature"
    ]
  }
}
